pid-online.name: PID-based identification in online services
pid-online.description: Secure identification to an online service using the PID stored in an EUDI Wallet.

pseudonym.name: Use of a pseudonym in online services
pseudonym.description: Interact with digital platforms without revealing your full identity, unless legally or functionally required to.

esignature.name: eSignature
esignature.description: Create advanced electronic signatures with the same legal validity as a handwritten signature.

payment-auth.name: Online payment authorisation
payment-auth.description: Enables online payments to be authorised via an EUDI Wallet.

open-bank-account.name: Open bank account
open-bank-account.description: Enables individuals to open a bank account online using their EUDI Wallet.

mdl.name: Mobile Driving Licence (mDL)
mdl.description: Proof of an individual's right to drive a certain kind of vehicle.

dtc.name: Digital Travel Credential (DTC)
dtc.description: A digital representation of the user's identity document such as an identity card, passport or another travel document.

epc.name: European Parking Card (EPC)
epc.description: Issued to persons with disabilities, recognising the right to certain reserved parking conditions and facilities.

vrc.name: Vehicle Registration Certificate (VRC)
vrc.description: Proves the registration and legal compliance of a vehicle with national and European road transport regulations.

disability-card.name: European Disability Card
disability-card.description: Serves as proof of recognised disability status/entitlement to disability services.

eprescription.name: e-Prescription
eprescription.description: Identify yourself in order to access e-prescriptions stored and presented via an EUDI Wallet.

ehic.name: European Health Insurance Card (EHIC)
ehic.description: Grants access to necessary healthcare when in another Member State.

public-warnings.name: Public warnings
public-warnings.description: Enables trusted public authorities to issue real-time or scheduled warnings and alerts, like for natural disasters.

age-verification.name: Age verification
age-verification.description: Prove you are above a specific age threshold (e.g., over 16, 18, or 21) using a verifiable digital credential.

ticket-pass.name: Ticket or pass
ticket-pass.description: Store, manage, and present digital tickets and access passes, like boarding passes or event tickets.

edu-credentials.name: Educational credentials
edu-credentials.description: Store, manage, and present digitally verifiable education-related credentials, like diplomas and certificates.

student-card.name: European student card
student-card.description: Enables students to store and present their student status.

proximity-id.name: Identification in proximity scenarios
proximity-id.description: Secure in-person identification for services where the transaction requires strong assurance of identity.

representation.name: Natural or legal person representation
representation.description: Enables users to act on behalf of another individual or an organisation using digitally verifiable credentials.

roles.label: Relying Party
roles.description: Entity accepting wallet credentials for authentication/verification

roles.label: EAA Issuer
roles.description: Entity issuing electronic attestations of attributes

2024/2977.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2977
2024/2977.description: Rules for person identification data and electronic attestations of attributes

2024/2979.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
2024/2979.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

2024/2981.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2981
2024/2981.description: Certification of European Digital Identity Wallets

TS01.title: Specification of EUDI Wallet Trust Mark

TS05.title: Common Formats and API for Relying Party Registration Information

TS06.title: Common Set of Relying Party Information to be Registered

TS12.title: Specification of electronic payments Strong Customer Authentication (SCA) implementation with the wallet

requirements.requirement: Register with competent supervisory authority before accepting EUDI Wallet
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties intending to rely on European Digital Identity Wallets must register with 
the competent authority in the Member State where they are established. Registration is 
a prerequisite for accepting wallet-based authentication.
requirements.legalText:
Where a relying party intends to rely upon European Digital Identity Wallets for the 
provision of public or private services by means of digital interaction, the relying 
party shall register in the Member State where it is established.

requirements.requirement: Provide registration information including identity and intended data requests
requirements.explanation:
During registration, relying parties must provide specific information including their 
identity, contact details, and importantly - the data they intend to request from users.
This enables oversight of data minimization compliance.
requirements.legalText:
The registration process shall be cost-effective and proportionate-to-risk. The relying 
party shall provide at least: (a) the information necessary to authenticate to European 
Digital Identity Wallets, which as a minimum includes: (i) the Member State in which the 
relying party is established; and (ii) the name of the relying party and, where applicable, 
its registration number as stated in an official record together with identification data 
of that official record; (b) the contact details of the relying party; (c) the intended 
use of European Digital Identity Wallets, including an indication of the data to be 
requested by the relying party from users.

requirements.requirement: Request only data indicated during registration
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties are strictly limited to requesting only the data they declared during 
registration. Requesting additional data beyond the registered scope is prohibited.
requirements.legalText:
Relying parties shall not request users to provide any data other than that indicated 
pursuant to paragraph 2, point (c).

requirements.requirement: Notify changes to registration information without delay
requirements.explanation:
If the relying party's registration information changes (e.g., new data fields requested, 
contact details updated), they must promptly notify the Member State.
requirements.legalText:
Relying parties registered in accordance with this Article shall inform Member States 
without delay about any changes to the information provided in the registration 
pursuant to paragraph 2.

requirements.requirement: Identify yourself to wallet users when requesting data
requirements.explanation:
When relying parties request data from wallet users, they must clearly identify 
themselves. The wallet displays the RP's identity information from their access 
certificate to enable user trust decisions.
requirements.legalText:
Where relying parties intend to rely upon European Digital Identity Wallets, they 
shall identify themselves to the user.

requirements.requirement: Accept pseudonymous authentication where legal identity is not required
requirements.explanation:
When a user's legal identity is not required by law, relying parties must accept 
pseudonymous authentication. Users cannot be forced to reveal their real identity 
when pseudonymous access is sufficient.
requirements.legalText:
Relying parties shall be responsible for carrying out the procedure for authenticating 
and validating person identification data and electronic attestation of attributes 
requested from European Digital Identity Wallets. Relying parties shall not refuse the 
use of pseudonyms, where the identification of the user is not required by Union or 
national law.

requirements.requirement: Support mandated credential formats (ISO 18013-5 and W3C VC)
requirements.explanation:
Wallet solutions must support person identification data in both ISO/IEC 18013-5:2021 
(mDL/mDoc) format and W3C Verifiable Credentials Data Model 1.1. Relying parties 
accepting PID must be able to process at least one of these formats.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet solutions support the usage of person 
identification data and electronic attestations of attributes issued in compliance 
with the list of standards set out in Annex II.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
legalSourceInfo.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

requirements.requirement: Implement presentation protocols (ISO 18013-5, ISO 18013-7)
requirements.explanation:
For remote and proximity presentation of credentials, relying parties must implement 
the standardized protocols specified in the Annex to Regulation 2024/2982.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet solutions support protocols and interfaces 
for the presentation of attributes to wallet-relying parties, remotely, and where 
appropriate in proximity, in accordance with the standards set out in the Annex.

requirements.requirement: Support selective disclosure of attributes
requirements.explanation:
The technical implementation must support selective disclosure, allowing users to 
share only specific attributes (e.g., "over 18") rather than full credentials.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet solutions support the selective disclosure 
of attributes of personal identification data and of electronic attestations of 
attributes.

requirements.requirement: Comply with WebAuthn specification for pseudonym generation
requirements.explanation:
When accepting pseudonymous authentication from wallet units, relying parties must 
support the WebAuthn specification as mandated in Annex V of the Integrity regulation.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet units shall support the generation of pseudonyms for wallet users in compliance 
with the technical specifications set out in Annex V.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
legalSourceInfo.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

requirements.requirement: Support relying-party-specific pseudonyms
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties may request a pseudonym that is unique and specific to them. This 
enables unlinkable authentication across different relying parties while allowing 
the same RP to recognize returning users.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet units shall support the generation, upon the request of a wallet-relying party, 
of a pseudonym which is specific and unique to that wallet-relying party and provide 
this pseudonym to the wallet-relying party, either standalone or in combination with 
any person identification data or electronic attribute attestation requested by that 
wallet-relying party.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
legalSourceInfo.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

requirements.requirement: Verify proof of possession of private keys
requirements.explanation:
When receiving credentials, relying parties must verify that the wallet possesses 
the private key corresponding to the public key used in the cryptographic binding.
This prevents replay attacks and credential theft.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet units support proving the possession of 
private keys corresponding to public keys used in cryptographic bindings.

requirements.requirement: Use valid Wallet-Relying Party Access Certificate
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must use a valid wallet-relying party access certificate when 
interacting with wallet units. This certificate authenticates the RP to the wallet.
requirements.legalText:
Regarding the protocols and interfaces referred to in Articles 4 and 5, wallet 
providers shall ensure that wallet units authenticate and validate the wallet-relying 
party access certificates where interacting with wallet-relying parties.

requirements.requirement: Support data erasure request protocol
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must implement the protocol allowing wallet users to request erasure 
of personal data that was shared through the wallet, supporting GDPR Article 17 rights.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet units support protocols and interfaces 
allowing wallet users to request from wallet-relying parties, with whom they have 
interacted through those wallet units, the erasure of their personal data provided 
through those wallet units, in accordance with Article 17 of Regulation (EU) 2016/679.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Accept EUDI Wallet for online services requiring e-ID
requirements.explanation:
When a public sector body requires electronic identification to access an online 
service, they must also accept EUDI Wallets provided in accordance with the regulation.
requirements.legalText:
Where Member States require electronic identification and authentication to access 
an online service provided by a public sector body, they shall also accept European 
Digital Identity Wallets that are provided in accordance with this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Private sector: Accept EUDI Wallet where strong authentication is mandated
requirements.explanation:
Private relying parties (except micro/small enterprises) must accept EUDI Wallets 
when strong user authentication is required by law or contract in specified sectors.
requirements.legalText:
Where private relying parties that provide services, with the exception of 
microenterprises and small enterprises [...], are required by Union or national law 
to use strong user authentication for online identification or where strong user 
authentication for online identification is required by contractual obligation, 
including in the areas of transport, energy, banking, financial services, social 
security, health, drinking water, postal services, digital infrastructure, education 
or telecommunications, those private relying parties shall [...] also accept European 
Digital Identity Wallets that are provided in accordance with this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Very large online platforms: Accept EUDI Wallet for user authentication
requirements.explanation:
Providers of very large online platforms (as defined in DSA Article 33) must accept 
EUDI Wallets for user authentication upon voluntary user request.
requirements.legalText:
Where providers of very large online platforms as referred to in Article 33 of 
Regulation (EU) 2022/2065 [...] require user authentication for access to online 
services, they shall also accept and facilitate the use of European Digital Identity 
Wallets that are provided in accordance with this Regulation for user authentication 
only upon the voluntary request of the user and in respect of the minimum data 
necessary for the specific online service for which authentication is requested.

requirements.requirement: Support wallet-based Strong Customer Authentication (SCA)
requirements.explanation:
Payment service providers must accept the EUDI Wallet as a means of performing 
Strong Customer Authentication for payment transactions and account access.
requirements.legalText:
Where private relying parties that provide services [...] are required by Union or 
national law to use strong user authentication for online identification [...] 
including in the areas of [...] banking, financial services [...] those private 
relying parties shall [...] also accept European Digital Identity Wallets.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic signatures regardless of electronic form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect or admissibility of an electronic signature 
solely because it is in electronic form or doesn't meet qualified signature requirements.
requirements.legalText:
An electronic signature shall not be denied legal effect and admissibility as evidence 
in legal proceedings solely on the grounds that it is in an electronic form or that it 
does not meet the requirements for qualified electronic signatures.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified electronic signatures as equivalent to handwritten
requirements.explanation:
Qualified electronic signatures have the equivalent legal effect of a handwritten 
signature and must be treated as such by relying parties.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic signature shall have the equivalent legal effect of a 
handwritten signature.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified signatures from all Member States
requirements.explanation:
Cross-border recognition is mandatory. A qualified electronic signature issued in 
any EU Member State must be recognized in all other Member States.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic signature based on a qualified certificate issued in one 
Member State shall be recognised as a qualified electronic signature in all other 
Member States.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Accept advanced signatures in defined formats
requirements.explanation:
Public sector relying parties requiring advanced electronic signatures must accept 
them in the formats defined by Commission implementing acts, ensuring interoperability.
requirements.legalText:
If a Member State requires an advanced electronic signature to use an online service 
offered by, or on behalf of, a public sector body, that Member State shall recognise 
advanced electronic signatures, advanced electronic signatures based on a qualified 
certificate for electronic signatures, and qualified electronic signatures in at least 
the formats or using methods defined in the implementing acts referred to in paragraph 5.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Not require higher than qualified signature for cross-border
requirements.explanation:
For cross-border services, public sector bodies cannot require a security level 
higher than qualified electronic signature, ensuring accessibility across Member States.
requirements.legalText:
Member States shall not request for cross-border use in an online service offered by 
a public sector body an electronic signature at a higher security level than the 
qualified electronic signature.

requirements.requirement: Validate qualified electronic signatures correctly
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties should use a validation process that confirms the qualified signature's 
validity, including checking certificates, revocation status, time of signing, and 
data integrity.
requirements.legalText:
The process for the validation of a qualified electronic signature shall confirm 
the validity of a qualified electronic signature provided that: (a) the certificate 
that supports the signature was, at the time of signing, a qualified certificate 
[...]; (b) the qualified certificate was issued by a qualified trust service provider 
and was valid at the time of signing; (c) the signature validation data corresponds 
to the data provided to the relying party; (d) the unique set of data representing 
the signatory in the certificate is correctly provided to the relying party; 
(e) the use of any pseudonym is clearly indicated to the relying party [...].

requirements.requirement: Validate advanced signatures based on qualified certificates
requirements.explanation:
When receiving advanced electronic signatures based on qualified certificates, relying 
parties should ensure proper validation according to the defined process.
requirements.legalText:
The process for the validation of an advanced electronic signature based on a 
qualified certificate shall confirm the validity of an advanced electronic signature 
based on a qualified certificate, provided that: (a) the certificate that supports 
the signature was, at the time of signing, a qualified certificate [...]; 
(c) the signature validation data corresponds to the data provided to the relying party; 
(d) the unique set of data representing the signatory in the certificate is correctly 
provided to the relying party; (e) the use of any pseudonym is clearly indicated to 
the relying party [...].

requirements.requirement: Consider using qualified validation services
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties may use qualified validation services to validate qualified electronic 
signatures, receiving automated, reliable validation results.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified validation service for qualified electronic signatures may only be 
provided by a qualified trust service provider who: (a) provides validation in 
compliance with Article 32(1); and (b) allows relying parties to receive the result 
of the validation process in an automated manner, which is reliable, efficient and 
bears the advanced electronic signature or advanced electronic seal of the provider 
of the qualified validation service.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic seals regardless of electronic form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect or admissibility of an electronic seal 
solely because it is in electronic form.
requirements.legalText:
An electronic seal shall not be denied legal effect and admissibility as evidence 
in legal proceedings solely on the grounds that it is in an electronic form or that 
it does not meet the requirements for qualified electronic seals.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified electronic seals' presumptions
requirements.explanation:
Qualified electronic seals enjoy the presumption of data integrity and origin correctness.
RPs should rely on these presumptions when verifying sealed data.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic seal shall enjoy the presumption of integrity of the data and 
of correctness of the origin of that data to which the qualified electronic seal is linked.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified electronic seals from all Member States
requirements.explanation:
Cross-border recognition is mandatory. A qualified electronic seal issued in 
any EU Member State must be recognized in all other Member States.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic seal based on a qualified certificate issued in one Member State 
shall be recognised as a qualified electronic seal in all other Member States.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Accept advanced seals in defined formats
requirements.explanation:
Public sector relying parties requiring advanced electronic seals must accept 
them in the formats defined by Commission implementing acts.
requirements.legalText:
If a Member State requires an advanced electronic seal in order to use an online service 
offered by, or on behalf of, a public sector body, that Member State shall recognise 
advanced electronic seals, advanced electronic seals based on a qualified certificate 
for electronic seals and qualified electronic seals at least in the formats or using 
methods defined in the implementing acts referred to in paragraph 5.

requirements.requirement: Validate qualified electronic seals correctly
requirements.explanation:
Articles 32-34 for signature validation apply mutatis mutandis to electronic seals.
RPs should validate seals using the same processes as signatures.
requirements.legalText:
Articles 32, 33 and 34 shall apply mutatis mutandis to the validation and 
preservation of qualified electronic seals.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic time stamps regardless of electronic form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect of an electronic time stamp solely 
because it is in electronic form.
requirements.legalText:
An electronic time stamp shall not be denied legal effect and admissibility as 
evidence in legal proceedings solely on the grounds that it is in an electronic 
form or that it does not meet the requirements of the qualified electronic time stamp.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified time stamps' presumptions
requirements.explanation:
Qualified electronic time stamps enjoy the presumption of accuracy of date/time 
and integrity of the bound data. RPs should rely on these presumptions.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic time stamp shall enjoy the presumption of the accuracy of 
the date and the time it indicates and the integrity of the data to which the 
date and time are bound.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified time stamps from all Member States
requirements.explanation:
Cross-border recognition is mandatory. A qualified electronic time stamp issued 
in any EU Member State must be recognized in all other Member States.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic time stamp issued in one Member State shall be recognised 
as a qualified electronic time stamp in all Member States.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic registered delivery data regardless of form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect of data sent/received using electronic 
registered delivery services solely because it is electronic.
requirements.legalText:
Data sent and received using an electronic registered delivery service shall not 
be denied legal effect and admissibility as evidence in legal proceedings solely 
on the grounds that it is in an electronic form or that it does not meet the 
requirements of the qualified electronic registered delivery service.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified registered delivery presumptions
requirements.explanation:
Qualified electronic registered delivery services enjoy presumptions of data integrity,
sender/addressee identification, and date/time accuracy.
requirements.legalText:
Data sent and received using a qualified electronic registered delivery service 
shall enjoy the presumption of the integrity of the data, the sending of that data 
by the identified sender, its receipt by the identified addressee and the accuracy 
of the date and time of sending and receipt indicated by the qualified electronic 
registered delivery service.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified certificates for website authentication
requirements.explanation:
Qualified certificates for website authentication issued in any Member State 
must be recognized in all other Member States.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified certificate for website authentication issued in one Member State 
shall be recognised as a qualified certificate for website authentication in 
all other Member States.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic attestations of attributes regardless of form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect of an electronic attestation of attributes 
solely because it is in electronic form.
requirements.legalText:
An electronic attestation of attributes shall not be denied legal effect or 
admissibility as evidence in legal proceedings on the sole ground that it is 
in electronic form or that it does not meet the requirements for qualified 
electronic attestations of attributes.

requirements.requirement: Recognize legal effect of qualified EAA and public sector EAA
requirements.explanation:
Qualified EAA and attestations issued by public sector bodies responsible for 
authentic sources have the same legal effect as paper attestations.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic attestation of attributes and attestations of attributes 
issued by, or on behalf of, a public sector body responsible for an authentic 
source shall have the same legal effect as lawfully issued attestations in paper form.

requirements.requirement: Recognize public sector EAA from all Member States
requirements.explanation:
Cross-border recognition is mandatory. EAA issued by a public sector body in 
one Member State must be recognized in all other Member States.
requirements.legalText:
An attestation of attributes issued by or on behalf of a public sector body 
responsible for an authentic source in one Member State shall be recognised 
as an attestation of attributes issued by or on behalf of a public sector body 
responsible for an authentic source in all Member States.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronically archived data regardless of form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect of electronically preserved data solely 
because it is electronic or not preserved using a qualified archiving service.
requirements.legalText:
Electronic data and electronic documents preserved using an electronic archiving 
service shall not be denied legal effect or admissibility as evidence in legal 
proceedings on the sole ground that they are in electronic form or that they are 
not preserved using a qualified electronic archiving service.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified archiving service presumptions
requirements.explanation:
Data preserved using qualified electronic archiving enjoys the presumption of 
integrity and origin for the duration of preservation.
requirements.legalText:
Electronic data and electronic documents preserved using a qualified electronic 
archiving service shall enjoy the presumption of their integrity and of their 
origin for the duration of the preservation period by the qualified trust service provider.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic ledger records regardless of form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect of electronic ledger records solely 
because they are in electronic form.
requirements.legalText:
An electronic ledger shall not be denied legal effect or admissibility as evidence 
in legal proceedings solely on the grounds that it is in an electronic form or 
that it does not meet the requirements for qualified electronic ledgers.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified electronic ledger presumptions
requirements.explanation:
Data records in a qualified electronic ledger enjoy the presumption of unique, 
accurate sequential chronological ordering and integrity.
requirements.legalText:
Data records contained in a qualified electronic ledger shall enjoy the presumption 
of their unique and accurate sequential chronological ordering and of their integrity.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Recognize e-ID from other Member States
requirements.explanation:
When requiring electronic identification for online services, public sector RPs 
must accept notified e-ID means from other Member States at substantial/high levels.
requirements.legalText:
When an electronic identification using an electronic identification means and 
authentication is required under national law or by administrative practice to 
access a service provided by a public sector body online in one Member State, 
the electronic identification means issued in another Member State shall be 
recognised in the first Member State for the purposes of cross-border authentication 
for that service online.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Ensure unequivocal identity matching for cross-border
requirements.explanation:
When acting as relying parties for cross-border services, public sector bodies 
must ensure unequivocal identity matching for users with notified e-ID or EUDI Wallets.
requirements.legalText:
When acting as relying parties for cross-border services, Member States shall 
ensure unequivocal identity matching for natural persons using notified electronic 
identification means or European Digital Identity Wallets.

requirements.requirement: Protect personal data used for identity matching
requirements.explanation:
For cross-border identity matching, appropriate technical and organisational measures 
must be in place to protect personal data and prevent user profiling.
requirements.legalText:
Member States shall provide for technical and organisational measures to ensure 
a high level of protection of personal data used for identity matching and to 
prevent the profiling of users.

requirements.requirement: Access certificate revocation status information
requirements.explanation:
Qualified trust service providers must provide RPs with certificate validity/revocation 
information. RPs should use this to verify certificate status before relying on them.
requirements.legalText:
With regard to paragraph 3, qualified trust service providers issuing qualified 
certificates shall provide to any relying party information on the validity or 
revocation status of qualified certificates issued by them. This information 
shall be made available at least on a per certificate basis at any time and 
beyond the validity period of the certificate in an automated manner that is 
reliable, free of charge and efficient.

requirements.requirement: Request only necessary and proportionate attributes
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties shall only request attributes that are necessary and proportionate 
for the specific service. Over-requesting data violates data minimization principles.
requirements.legalText:
Relying parties shall not request users to provide any data other than that indicated 
pursuant to paragraph 2, point (c).

requirements.requirement: Support selective disclosure of attributes
requirements.explanation:
Systems must be capable of processing selectively disclosed attributes. Users 
should not be forced to reveal more data than necessary (e.g., verifying "over 18" 
without revealing exact birth date).
requirements.legalText:
European Digital Identity Wallets shall enable the user, in a manner that is 
user-friendly, transparent, and traceable by the user, to: (a) securely request, 
obtain, select, combine, store, delete, share and present, under the sole control 
of the user, person identification data and, where applicable, in combination with 
electronic attestations of attributes, to authenticate to relying parties online 
and, where appropriate, in offline mode, in order to access public and private 
services, while ensuring that selective disclosure of data is possible.

requirements.requirement: Do not track wallet usage across services (unlinkability)
requirements.explanation:
The technical framework must prevent tracking or correlation of wallet usage 
across different services, unless the user explicitly consents.
requirements.legalText:
The technical framework of the European Digital Identity Wallet shall: (a) not allow 
providers of electronic attestations of attributes or any other party, after the 
issuance of the attestation of attributes, to obtain data that allows transactions 
or user behaviour to be tracked, linked or correlated, or knowledge of transactions 
or user behaviour to be otherwise obtained, unless explicitly authorised by the user.

requirements.requirement: Enable privacy preserving unlinkability for non-identified attestations
requirements.explanation:
When attestations don't require user identification, privacy-preserving techniques 
must ensure unlinkability across different relying parties.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet units [...] enable privacy preserving 
techniques which ensure unlinkability where the electronic attestations of 
attributes do not require the identification of the wallet user, when presenting 
attestations or person identification data across different wallet-relying parties.

requirements.requirement: Allow pseudonyms where legal identity is not required
requirements.explanation:
Users cannot be prohibited from using pseudonyms when there is no legal requirement 
for identity verification.
requirements.legalText:
Without prejudice to specific rules of Union or national law requiring users to 
identify themselves or to the legal effect given to pseudonyms under national law, 
the use of pseudonyms that are chosen by the user shall not be prohibited.

requirements.requirement: Process data in accordance with GDPR
requirements.explanation:
All personal data received from wallets must be processed in full compliance 
with GDPR, including lawful basis, storage limitation, and data subject rights.
requirements.legalText:
This Regulation is without prejudice to Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of the European 
Parliament and of the Council.

requirements.requirement: Maintain alternative means of identification
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties may maintain alternative authentication methods. EUDI Wallet 
acceptance requirements do not prevent offering other identification means.
requirements.legalText:
The use of European Digital Identity Wallets shall be voluntary. Access to public 
and private services, access to the labour market and freedom to conduct business 
shall not in any way be restricted or made disadvantageous to natural or legal 
persons that do not use European Digital Identity Wallets. It shall remain possible 
to access public and private services by other existing identification and 
authentication means.

requirements.requirement: Support reporting to data protection authorities
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must be prepared to be reported to data protection authorities 
through the wallet's reporting mechanism if users suspect unlawful data requests.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet units allow wallet users to easily report 
wallet-relying parties to supervisory authorities established under Article 51 of 
Regulation (EU) 2016/679.

requirements.requirement: Perform data protection impact assessments for wallet data processing
requirements.explanation:
Recital 17 emphasizes that relying parties should comply with GDPR safeguards, 
particularly by performing data protection impact assessments and consulting 
data protection authorities prior to processing where there is high risk.
requirements.legalText:
Relying parties should comply with the safeguards offered by Articles 35 and 36 
of [Regulation (EU) 2016/679], in particular by performing data protection impact 
assessments and by consulting the competent data protection authorities prior to 
data processing where data protection impact assessments indicate that the 
processing would result in a high risk.

requirements.requirement: Apply data minimization - request only necessary data
requirements.explanation:
Recital 56 emphasizes that any request for information should be necessary, 
proportionate to the intended use, and in line with data minimisation principles.
requirements.legalText:
Any request by the relying party for information from the user of a European 
Digital Identity Wallet should be necessary for, and proportionate to, the 
intended use in a given case, should be in line with the principle of data 
minimisation and should ensure transparency as regards which data is shared 
and for what purposes.

requirements.requirement: Accept pseudonymous access where identification not legally required
requirements.explanation:
Recital 60 clarifies that unless specific rules require user identification, 
accessing services by using a pseudonym should not be prohibited.
requirements.legalText:
Unless specific rules of Union or national law require users to identify 
themselves, accessing services by using a pseudonym should not be prohibited.

requirements.requirement: Enable selective disclosure of attributes
requirements.explanation:
Recital 59 emphasizes that selective disclosure is a core design feature of 
wallets, allowing users to share only necessary parts of their data.
requirements.legalText:
Selective disclosure is a concept empowering the owner of data to disclose 
only certain parts of a larger data set, in order for the receiving entity 
to obtain only such information as is necessary for the provision of a 
service requested by a user. The European Digital Identity Wallet should 
technically enable the selective disclosure of attributes to relying parties.

requirements.requirement: Very large online platforms must accept wallet authentication
requirements.explanation:
Recital 57 states that very large online platforms (as defined in DSA) that 
require authentication should accept EUDI Wallets upon user request, while 
respecting data minimisation and pseudonym rights.
requirements.legalText:
Where very large online platforms...require users to be authenticated in order 
to access online services, those platforms should be required to accept the use 
of European Digital Identity Wallets upon the voluntary request of the user. 
Users should be under no obligation to use a European Digital Identity Wallet 
to access private services... However, if users wish to do so, very large online 
platforms should accept them for that purpose, while respecting the principle 
of data minimisation and the right of the users to use freely chosen pseudonyms.
